column4: take a look at "wall".. perhaps you can make it do what you want
have you checked the man page for apt-get?
reading  man pages, yes, but not exactly sure what it would be called...
try "man apt-get"  then press "/" and type "specific" and press enter.. that should get you to the right place
I think it's pkg_version_number you're looking for
looking at that now, thanks for the hint
as stated, when I use that syntax I get the error stating that the package could not be found... I'm trying -t to target the release I want
what I'm not able to figure out is how to determine which versions are available
they might remove packages from the repos when updated ones come in..
thank you, that returns the version I've been installing, so I guess that confirms what I have in the package.
I think that will return all available versions of a package.. if you only get one hit it might be the only version available
that being said it appears as though I'm sol and will have to build from source
or try using the main repository.. perhaps it has more versions of the packages available than your local mirror
I'm using the us.archive.ubuntu.com repo source
are you suggesting there is another source I should consider using?
I'm not sure where the main ubuntu repository is located..
